questions.text: To detect vaginal cells on a person who is accused of rape,  which test will you use?
questions.solution:
Lugol's iodine test will be used to detect the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused. It shows brown color on filter paper due to the presence of glycogen in epithelial cells of the vagina. 

Other options:

Option A: Florence test is used to detect choline in that originates from seminal vesicles. It produces dark brown, rhombic, or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide if semen is present. 

Option B: Barberio test is used to detect spermatic fluid. It produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate when picric acid is added to spermatic fluid. 

Option D: Precipitin test is used for species identification of semen stain. A positive test will confirm human origin.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the image below
questions.solution:
The cell marked in the image is a mast cell stained with toluidine blue. Mast cell granules contain acid proteoglycan that binds basic blue such as toluidine blue.

Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin-stained sections, and special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and are widely distributed in connective tissues. They play an important role in immediate hypersensitivity and both acute and chronic inflammation.

Mast cells express a receptor on their surface that binds to the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulate. This results in the release of:

  • Granule contents: Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin.
  • Lipid mediators: Leucotriene C4, D4, prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor.
  • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1

These mediators released from mast cells play an important role in the pathogenesis of immediate/type 1 hypersensitivity.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Some of the important disorders associated with mast cell activity are bronchial asthma, urticaria, mastocytosis, interstitial cystitis and neurofibroma.

questions.text:
Match the malignancies in column A with the genes in column B
Column A Column B
1. Pleomorphic adenoma a. Rb
2. Burkitt lymphoma b. nMyc
3. Neuroblastoma c. cMyc
 4. Retinoblastoma d. Plag 1
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is option C 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, and 4-a.

1. Pleomorphic adenoma d. Plag 1
2. Burkitt lymphoma c. cMyc
3. Neuroblastoma b. nMyc
4. Retinoblastoma a. Rb

Pleomorphic adenoma is associated with chromosomal rearrangements that induce overexpression of PLAG1. It is the most common salivary gland and lacrimal gland neoplasm. Microscopically, it contains a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells.

Burkitt's lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). It is associated with the translocation cMYC gene on chromosome 8 to chromosome 14 or 22 - t(8:14) or t(8:22). Histopathology of the tumour reveals a starry sky appearance.

Neuroblastoma is a tumour derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumour in childhood. They are associated with the translocation nMYC gene. On histopathology small round blue cells and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes are seen.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with chromosomal rearrangements of the Rb gene. Microscopillay, Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are seen.

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
This type of drug is called a misbranded drug. A drug stating that 500mg of paracetamol is present in each tablet, but contains only 200mg is a misbranded drug, according to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 definition of misbranded drugs.

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics act, 1940, a misbranded drug is a drug if its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any statement, design, or device which makes any false claim for the drug or which is false or misleading in any particular.

Other options:

Option A: Spurious drugs include drugs manufactured under another drug or manufacturer's name, imitations of other drugs, and drugs with labels from a fictitious company or individual. It also includes drugs substituted partly or wholly by another drug or substance.

Option B: Adulterated drugs include those drugs that contain filthy, or decomposed substances, substances that are injurious to health, or if the drug harmful substances to reduce the quality or strength of the drug. It also includes drugs that were prepared in unsanitary conditions.

Option C: The term unethical drug is not standard terminology in pharmacology. However, the term ethical drug is sometimes used to describe those drugs that are available only by prescription of a medical practitioner.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient presents with sudden diminishing vision associated with relative afferent pupillary defect in the right eye. On examination, the left eye is normal. Which of the following investigations would you do next?
  1. MRI brain & orbit
  2. Myelin oligodendrocyte oligoprotein (MOG) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies
  3. Blood sugar
  4. Thyroid profile
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of optic neuritis. Sudden, progressive, and profound visual loss associated with relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is characteristic of optic neuritis. MRI brain & orbit, screening for circulating myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) & neuromyelitis optica (NMO) antibodies, and blood sugar levels are the next best investigations for optic neuritis.

A brain MRI is recommended in every patient after the first attack of optic neuritis. The 15-year cumulative probability of developing multiple sclerosis after an attack of optic neuritis is about 50%. It may remain an isolated event in some patients.

Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a severe type of optic neuritis which may occur bilaterally and is associated with myelitis. Detection of antibodies like MOG & NMO (also known as aquaporin-4 antibody) is diagnostic of the condition.

Optic neuritis is primarily treated with steroids. The blood sugar levels must be checked as steroids can worsen the glycemic control in individuals with DM which may precipitate hyperglycemia. 

Optic neuritis comprises inflammatory and demyelinating disorders of the optic nerve. It can be idiopathic, hereditary (Leber's disease), or due to demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis or neuromyelitis optica (Devic's disease). Anatomically, it can be papillitis, neuroretinitis, or retrobulbar neuritis. It is more common in women. 

Other symptoms include lowered dark adaptation and visual obscuration in bright light. Transient obscuration of vision on exposure to light (Uhthoff's symptom) and impaired depth perception (Pulfrich's phenomenon) may also be seen.

Marcus Gunn pupil which points to RAPD is a characteristic sign. It is elicited by the swinging flashlight test. One eye is illuminated with the flashlight and the response is noted. The same is done for the other eye. This is repeated multiple times (swinging). The normal response is constriction in both eyes. If there is RAPD in one eye, it will dilate when light is shone on it.

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of acute onset fever, and pain in the right lumbar region. It is associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E.coli and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy?

choices.text: Hospitalise, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.
Maintain urine output >50 ml/hr; Intravenous crystalloids can be given
Discharge if afebrile for 72 hrs; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy is option D. The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics have to be continued for 7 to 10 days.

Acute Pyelonephritis is one of the frequent and serious medical complications occurring in 2nd-trimester of pregnancy. The most common causative organism is E.coli.

Clinical features include sudden onset fever, chills, and aching pain in the lumbar region (usually unilateral). It is associated with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Tenderness in the costovertebral angle can be elicited on examination.

Diagnosis is confirmed by the collection of urine (preferably from catheterization) and analysis to look for leukocytes and bacteria.

Management protocol for pyelonephritis during pregnancy is 

  • Hospitalization is recommended for all patients. Very rare cases of uncomplicated pyelonephritis can be managed on an outpatient basis
  • Urine and blood (if temperature is > 39 degrees C) samples are collected for culture.
  • Aggressive intravenous hydration to maintain adequate urine output is the mainstay of treatment. A urinary output ≥50 mL/hr is maintained with intravenous crystalloids.
  • Vital signs such as blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and oxygen saturation along with urine output should be monitored for signs of worsening sepsis.
  • Empirical intravenous antibiotic therapy is started with ampicillin plus gentamicin, cefazolin or ceftriaxone. It is switched to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.
  • In case of persistent infection or lack of clinical improvement by 48 to 72 hours, renal sonography is recommended to look for urinary tract abnormalities (like obstruction or calculi).
  • The patient is discharged when afebrile for 24 hours and antimicrobial therapy is continued for 7 to 10 days.
  • Urine culture is repeated 1–2 weeks after antimicrobial therapy is completed.

Related Pearl: Asymptomatic bacteriuria

 
Asymptomatic bacteriuria: Urinary tract infection without any symptoms. Criteria for diagnosis are as follows:
 
Type of specimen Number of samples required  Minimum colony-forming units (cfu)/mL required for diagnosis of UTI
Midstream clean-catch urine specimen

For women: 2 consecutive samples

For men: single sample

 1,00,000 of the same bacterial species 
Catheterized urine specimen  Single sample

100 for asymptomatic bacteriuria (CA-ASB)

1000 for catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CA-UTI)
Suprapubic aspirate Single sample Any growth of microorganisms in the culture

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetic causes hypertension?
questions.solution:
The local anesthetic that causes hypertension is cocaine. This is due to the inhibition of norepinephrine at the adrenergic terminals leading to increased sympathetic stimulation. This effect occurs at all concentrations of cocaine and causes hypertension and ventricular ectopies.

Treatment is with the help of benzodiazepines, α-adrenergic antagonists and amiodarone.

All local anesthetics are mainly cardiodepressants causing reduced contractility and vasodilation. However, at low concentrations, all local anesthetics cause vasoconstriction due to the inhibition of nitric oxide. Only cocaine produces vasoconstriction and hypertension at all concentrations.

Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic like bupivacaine results in bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity. Management is by resuscitation followed by intralipid therapy. A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV is administered without delay.

Other adverse effects of local anesthetics include neurologic toxicity, respiratory depression, and hypersensitivity reactions. Nervous system manifestations are circumoral numbness, tongue paresthesia, dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

Systemic absorption of a local anesthetic depends on vascularity.

The highest blood concentrations are seen following:

  1. Intravenous (intraarterial) injection (maximum)
  2. Intercostal nerve blockade
  3. Paracervical block
  4. Caudal epidural block
  5. Lumbar epidural block
  6. Brachial plexus block
  7. Sciatic block
  8. Subcutaneous injection (minimum)

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: How does phagolysosome cause cell death?

choices.text: Is both intra and extra cellular
Can fuse with other organelles directly
Fuses with lysosome to form autophagolysosome

questions.solution:
Phagolysosomes cause cell death by the fusion of lysosomes to form autophagolysosomes. 
Autophagy is a process in which a cell eats its own contents. Cytoplasmic materials are delivered and degraded by the lysosome. It is a survival technique of the cell in nutrient deprivation states. 

The steps are:

  • An isolation membrane called phagophore is formed and nucleated.
  • Phagophore is derived from the ER with the help of plasma membrane and mitochondria
  • A double membrane-bound vesicle is formed from the isolation membrane called the autophagosome
  • Maturation of the autophagosome by fusion with lysosomes, called autophagolysosome. 

Apoptosis is a regulated mechanism of eliminating unwanted and damaged cells. It is initiated by enzymes called caspases and is executed by two different pathways. The mitochondrial pathway which is also known as the intrinsic pathway carries out the majority of the apoptosis. The death receptor pathway or the extrinsic pathway is initiated by plasma membrane death receptors. Both these pathways combine together and activate the caspase cascade which results in the final phase of apoptosis. 

Pyroptosis is a form of apoptosis mediated by fever-inducing cytokine IL-1. A multiprotein complex called inflammasome is activated when microorganisms enter the cell. It will in turn activate caspase 1 which cleaves the IL-1 precursor and releases its biologically active form.

questions.text:
Which is the correct sequence of steps in the isolation of desirable protein using recombinant DNA technology?
  1. Expression of protein and lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporation of genes into bacteria
  3. SDS PAGE
  4. Protein elution  
  5. Hybridization
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of isolation of desirable protein in recombinant DNA technology is 2, 1, 3, 5, 4.

I) Incorporation of genes into bacteria: The gene needed to produce the desired proteins is to be incorporated into the bacteria. This is done using cloning vectors like bacterial plasmids, phages, or cosmids. The DNA of interest is ligated into the vector DNA and is called recombinant DNA. This vector is then inserted into a competent host cell (eg: E.coli bacteria) where it is replicated.

II) Expression of protein and lysis of bacterial cell:  After incorporation of recombinant DNA, bacteria express the inserted gene and produce the desired protein on a large scale along with other indigenous bacterial proteins. To release these proteins bacterial cell is lysed.

III) SDS-PAGE (sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis): It is the most widely used method for determining the purity of a protein. After the proteins are released, to separate the desirable protein, we subject it to SDS-PAGE. It separates proteins based on molecular weight.

IV) Hybridization and blotting: It is done to confirm that the isolated protein is the desired protein. It is done using western blotting techniques on nitrocellulose paper.

V) Protein elution - extraction of the produced protein.

 

The practical applications of recombinant DNA technology include:

  • Gene mapping using techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
  • Producing proteins such as:
    • Interferons, tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
    • Insulin, growth hormone
    • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • Molecular analysis of disease, to detect gene variations and mutations.
  • Restriction Fragment Length polymorphism (RFLP) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)
  • Microsatellite DNA polymorphisms
  • Gene therapy and bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the healthcare unit that you are working on. His mother mentions that he had received the first dose of DPT vaccine at 6 weeks of age but has missed vaccination since then. What would you advise the patient?
questions.solution:
The advice for the patient is to give the second dose of DPT (Diphtheria-pertussis-tetanus).

DPT is a combined vaccine given for immunization against the three diseases diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus. It is given to infants as early as 6 weeks following birth. The pertussis component of the vaccine is not recommended beyond 6 years due to the decrease in the severity of pertussis infection with age. 7 years of age onwards, only Td combinations are used.

It is given in 3 doses with an interval of 4 weeks followed by booster doses at 18-24 months and at 5 years of age. The dosage is 0.5 mL and is given in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh intramuscularly. The immunization can be resumed without repeating the previous dose in case of any delayed or interrupted immunization.

Adverse effects include fever, and neurological complications such as encephalitis, convulsions, infantile spasms and Reye's syndrome. 

Anaphylaxis is a contraindication for subsequent vaccination with diphtheria, pertussis, or tetanus vaccine. Encephalopathy following vaccination is a contraindication for pertussis vaccine. DT is given for successive doses.

Events such as inconsolable cry, fever more than 40.5°C, seizures with or without fever are considered as precautions, and not contraindications for DTwP.

Note: IAP guidelines state that "temperature more than >40.5°C is a precaution and not contraindication". Park's 27th Ed states that "temperature above 40°C is a contraindication to DPT". This topic is controversial, however, IAP guidelines are commonly followed by practitioners.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculations are seen in:
questions.solution:
Tongue fasciculations are seen in spinal muscle atrophy (SMA).

Spinal muscle atrophy is a lower motor neuron disease with early-onset and occurs as a result of the loss of a protein called survival motor neuron (SMN).

Features of lower motor neuron disease include flaccid paralysis, muscle atrophy, fasciculations characterized by visible muscle twitches appearing as flickers under the skin, hypotonia (decreased muscle tone), hyporeflexia, or areflexia. 

Clinical forms of SMA are

  • In infantile SMA, the onset is very early and rapid. It is characterized by decreased fetal movements in the third trimester. In infancy, features include weak and floppy infant (hypotonic) and they lack muscle stretch reflex. Tongue fasciculations are typically seen in a severe form of SMA known as Werdnig-Hoffman disease. It can affect infants between 0-6 months.
  • Chronic childhood SMA has a slow onset and a progressive course.
  • Juvenile SMA is seen in late childhood with a slow course.

Nusinersen is approved for therapy and another treatment is systemic administration of adeno-associated virus to deliver the missing SMN gene.

Other options:

Option A: GBS or Guillain-Barre syndrome is an autoimmune polyradiculopathy with an acute onset. It is characterized mainly by motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbances. Weakness is seen more in the legs than arms. Other features include pain, bladder dysfunction, affected deep tendon reflexes, and proprioception. Hypotension and arrhythmias can also be seen 

Option C: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an x-linked recessive disorder due to mutation in the dystrophin gene. Typical features include proximal muscle weakness in lower extremities, calf muscle hypertrophy, intellectual disability, and heart failure. Myalgia without weakness and myoglobinuria can also be present.

Option D: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder due to autoimmune damage to the acetylcholine receptors. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatiguability. Weakness increases with usage. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can be seen. Proximal limb weakness is also present. 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: The organism with following life cycle is:
questions.solution:
The given life cycle is of Strongyloides stercoralis. 

The organism has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle. Humans are the natural host but morphologically indistinguishable strains may be seen in dogs and cats.

Filariform larvae are the infective form and there are two modes of infection:

  1. Penetration of skin by 3rd stage filariform larva.
  2. Autoinfection (external and internal).

The female worms present in the intestine lays eggs in the mucosa which hatches immediately, releasing the rhabditiform larva. The larva migrates into the lumen of the intestine and passes down to be released in the feces. The rhabditiform larva may change into filariform larva while passing through the bowel.

The filariform larvae in the bowel do not leave the host and become a source of autoinfection as they penetrate the colonic mucosa or perianal skin.

The rhabditiform larvae passed in the feces may undergo two types of development in the soil:

  1. Direct development: The rhabditiform larva moults twice on reaching the soil to become the infective filariform larva. The filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.
  2. Indirect development: The rhabditiform larvae develop into free-living males and females in the soil.

Other options:

Option B: Humans are the only natural host and the life-cycle of Ancylostoma duodenale is completed in a single host. The eggs laid by the female worms in the intestine are passed in feces. The embryo develops inside the egg and a rhabditiform larva hatches out in about 2 days.

The rhabditiform larva moults twice to form the filariform larva (infective stage). It penetrates the skin and enters the subcutaneous tissue.

Option C: Humans are the only natural host for Ascaris lumbricoides and have no intermediate host. The infection is acquired by ingestion of embryonated eggs (infective stage).

Option D: Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host and has no intermediate host. Embryonated eggs are the infective form. Infection is acquired by ingestion of the eggs. Autoinfection and retroinfection are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to detect DNA-protein interaction?
questions.solution:
The technique used to detect DNA-protein interaction is DNA footprinting.

The parts of DNA that are protein-bound (Eg: RNA polymerase bound to the promoter region of DNA) are resistant to digestion by nuclease enzymes. Since the nucleases are unable to cleave the protein-bound regions of DNA, when the cleaved DNA fragments are run on polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, there are missing bands indicating, protected sites of protein-bound DNA. These missing areas represent the footprint of the protected DNA-protein complexes. Hence DNA footprinting technique helps to identify the specific binding site of protein on a DNA sequence.

The image below illustrates the DNA footprinting technique.

Other options:

Option B: DNA fingerprinting uses RFLPs (restriction fragment length polymorphism) or repeat sequence DNA to identify a person's unique pattern of DNA. Polymorphisms are inherited differences found among individuals. with this technique, individuals can be differentiated by variations in their DNA sequence, using restriction endonucleases followed by gel electrophoresis, to visualize RFLPs. DNA fingerprinting is used for forensic analysis of crime scenes, and for paternity testing. 

Option C: ELISA uses antibodies linked to certain enzymes to detect certain antigens present in the sample.

Option D: Northern blotting technique can be used to detect RNA. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked in the image below?

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Blood is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery as the marked structure is the anterior part of the corpus callosum.

Corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway of the brain. The parts of the corpus callosum are the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium. 

 The image below shows the parts of the corpus callosum: 

Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. The frontal branch of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum and the central branch which supplies the rostrum. 

Central or perforating arteries arises from the circle of willis. They are again divided into the anteromedial, anterolateral, posteromedial and posterolateral groups. The anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery give rise to anteromedial group which supplies the rostrum of the corpus callosum. 


The image below shows the mid sagittal section of the brain:

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma?
questions.solution:
Perineural invasion is not observed in pleomorphic adenoma. Perineural invasion is seen in malignant salivary gland tumours like adenoid cystic carcinoma. 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common salivary gland and lacrimal gland neoplasm. They are commonly seen in the parotid. They are painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid.

Histologically, pleomorphic adenoma consists of epithelial and mesenchymal components.

  • Epithelial components consist of
    • Ductal cells, myoepithelial cells organized as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, or sheets of cells
    • Squamous metaplasia with the formation of keratin pearls may be present
  • Mesenchymal components consist of
    • Loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing cartilage (due to chondroid differentiation) and bone

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Clinical features

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Lift the ear lobe
  • Free from deeper structures

FNAC is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic adenoma. Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment  by performing superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pallor was seen and hemoglobin was found to be 6 gm/dL. What finding will be seen on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Microcytic hypochromic cells will be seen on the peripheral smear. An elderly female presenting with fatigue and dyspnea with severe anaemia is suggestive of iron deficiency anaemia(IDA). The peripheral smear of IDA shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement and, chronic blood loss. The cause of iron deficiency anaemia in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth) and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor.
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells.

The image given below shows a microcytic hypochromic blood picture in a peripheral smear

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anaemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight(kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000mg (for stores)

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures?
questions.solution:
Canagliflozin is associated with an increased risk of fractures. 

Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 is a Na+-glucose cotransporter that is located in the proximal convoluted tubule. They reabsorb glucose and sodium from the tubular lumen back into the blood through the epithelial cells. SGLT2 inhibitors block the transport of glucose in the proximal tubule and promote glycosuria and hence, lowering blood glucose.

The currently available SGLT2 inhibitors are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin. Other than decreasing blood glucose they also decrease blood pressure and, cause weight loss of 2–4 kg. Empagliflozin and canagliflozin reduce the risk for major cardiovascular events.

The main side effect of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increase in lower urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections. This is because of their glycosuric properties. A recent warning from the FDA says that SGLT2 inhibitors may increase the risk of fractures. They also affect circulating levels of parathyroid hormone, and 1,25-hydroxy vitamin D thereby affecting the mineral balance in bone.

Other options:

Option A: Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that acts as a peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ agonist in the adipose tissue which increases insulin sensitivity and adipose differentiation. Side effects are weight gain, edema, and increased risk of fractures. Compared to rosiglitazone, canagliflozin is commonly used in clinical practice. American diabetes association recommends canagliflozin as the first-line drug along with metformin, in patients with a high risk of cardiovascular disease, renal failure, and heart failure. Even when thiazolidinediones are required, clinicians prefer pioglitazone over rosiglitazone due to the higher risk of cardiovascular-related mortality in rosiglitazone. Therefore, canagliflozin would be a better option compared to rosiglitazone. 

Option B: Liraglutide is a long-acting glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist. Nausea, diarrhea, and acute pancreatitis are some frequent side effects.

Option C: Voglibose reduces the intestinal absorption of starch, dextrin, and disaccharides by inhibiting the action of α-glucosidase in the intestinal brush border. The most prominent adverse effects are malabsorption, flatulence, diarrhea, and abdominal bloating.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells in a healthy adult?
questions.solution:
The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1. 

T lymphocytes constitute 60-70% of lymphocytes in the blood while mature B cells account for 10-20%.

T cells are of three types: Helper T cells, cytotoxic T cells, and regulatory T cells. T lymphocytes develop in the thymus.

B lymphocytes develop from precursors present in the bone marrow. They differentiate to form either plasma cells or memory B cells. Plasma cells produce antibodies after stimulation by the antigen.

Lymphocyte recirculation is particularly important for T cells, as B cells do not have to move to the site of infection as the antibodies produced are circulated through blood.

questions.text: The image below is indicative of which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows the characteristic Schiller Duval body consistent with a yolk sac tumor. 

A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation.

It is most oftenly seen in children and young women. It usually presents as abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass. 

Grossly, the yolk-sac tumor appears yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and forms solid mass.

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

Yolk-sac tumors are rich in alpha-fetoprotein. Therefore, serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein can serve as a reliable tumor marker in post treatment surveillance.

Other options:

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes.

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in Kruckenberg tumor.

Option D: Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumours.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hip dislocation?

choices.text: Posterior dislocation of hip has flexion and adduction
Vessel injury more common in anterior
Nerve injury more common in anterior
Posterior dislocation is more common than anterior

questions.solution:
Statement C is false. Nerve injury is more common in posterior hip dislocation. The sciatic nerve, lying behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum is most commonly involved here.

Sciatic nerve injury is seen in 10-20 % of cases with posterior hip dislocation. It is usually a neuropraxia type of injury and resolves spontaneously. But, if it is suspected after a reduction maneuver, immediate exploration must be carried out.

Posterior hip dislocation is the commonest type of hip dislocation (80%), commonly seen following dashboard injuries. The patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformities.

X-ray findings include:

  • Femoral head lying above and behind the acetabulum and appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualized as the thigh is internally rotated
  • Femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen

Treatment includes an early reduction to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis. Closed reduction under sedation or general anaesthesia is done in most cases. If there is an associated femoral neck fracture, the closed reduction should not be attempted as it can lead to the displacement of the femoral neck and disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head.

Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident. The affected limb in this condition will be abducted, externally rotated, and slightly flexed.

Note: Although vascular injuries are seen in posterior dislocations as well, they are most likely with anterior dislocation. This is because of the femoral artery lying anterior to the head. (statement B)

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

West syndrome is a severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of infantile spasms that occur in clusters, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG). Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes (shown below). 

Cryptogenic cases (unknown etiology) have normal development prior to onset, while symptomatic West syndrome is associated with preceding developmental delay owing to perinatal encephalopathies, metabolic disorders, or malformations.

Hormonal therapy, such as ACTH injections or oral steroids, is the preferred treatment for West syndrome. The patient's response is monitored through awake and asleep EEGs conducted at 1, 2, and 4th weeks of starting hormonal therapy. Side effects may include hypertension, electrolyte imbalance, infections, hyperglycemia and/or glycosuria, and gastric ulcers. 

Vigabatrin is a first-line treatment option for infantile spasms in patients with tuberous sclerosis and is also considered a second-line choice if hormonal therapy has been unsuccessful in other cases of infantile spasms. 

The ketogenic diet is considered a third-line therapy for infantile spasms. Other alternative treatment options for spasms include valproate, benzodiazepines (such as nitrazepam and clonazepam), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, pyridoxine, and intravenous gamma globulin (IVIG).

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME)/ Janz syndrome starts in early adolescence and is characterized by myoclonic jerks in the morning. EEG shows generalized irregular 4- to 6-Hz spike-and-wave activity, particularly after awakening. Valproate is considered the most effective medication. Lamotrigine, levetiracetam, and topiramate are also approved for JME.

Option B: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening. They are partial seizures with no loss of consciousness. They resolve in adulthood. Treatment with carbamazepine is useful.

Option D: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is seen in 2-10 years and is characterized by a triad of developmental delay, multiple seizures (atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures), and specific EEG changes (1 to 2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts). Treatment with topiramate, clobazam, felbamate, lamotrigine, and valproate is useful.

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine forms which of the following?
questions.solution:
Deamination of methylated cytosine forms thymine.

Deamination is the removal of an amino group(NH2) from a chemical compound. Enzymes that catalyze this reaction are called deaminases. Deamination of 5-methylcytosine forms thymine. 

Other significant deaminations are given below:

  • Deamination of adenosine forms inosine. This is a metabolic step involved in uric acid formation by purine catabolism. It is mediated by the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). ADA deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells and patients suffer from Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • Deamination of cytosine leads to uracil formation - The production of apolipoprotein B-48 (apoB-48) in the intestine is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. This involves post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil by enzyme cytidine deaminase. This converts sense codon (CAA) in the mRNA to nonsense codon (UAA)at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.
  • Deamination of guanine forms xanthine. This is a metabolic step involved in uric acid formation by purine catabolism.

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.solution:
All of the following options are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except an posterior position of cervix (Option D). An anterior cervix favors a higher bishop's score, which means a higher chance of preterm labor as compared to the posterior cervix. The midline position of the cervix has also shown higher incidence of preterm labor as compared to posterior cervix.

Preterm labor (PTL) is defined as labor occuring between 20weeks to 37th completed week of gestation.

Diagnostic criteria of preterm labour include:

  • Regular uterine contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 min with/without pain. 
  • Cervix dilatation ≥2 cm 
  • Cervix effacement ≥80% 
  • Length of cervix (on TVS) ≤2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding PV

Predictors of preterm labor:

  • Clinical predictors:
    • History of prior preterm birth
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Active genital tract infection
  • Biophysical predictors:
    • Uterine contractions ≥4/hour
    • Bishop score ≥4
    • Cervical length (on TVS) ≤25 mm
  • Biochemical predictors:
    • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) positive (>50 ng/mL) in cervico-vaginal discharge 
    • Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except:
questions.solution:
All of the structures except pyriformis are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Pyriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis. 

The dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 rami give rise to the superior gluteal nerve. It is accompanied by superior gluteal vessels. This nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis and divides into superior and inferior branches. It supplies gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.

The dorsal branches of the S1 and S2 rami give rise to the nerve to the piriformis. 

Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus act as the abductors of the hip joint. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. If the ipsilateral abductors are normal, the pelvis remains in a horizontal position. If the ipsilateral abductors are weak, then the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side. This is called positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text: Which of the following types of inhibition is depicted in the given Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
The given graph shows competitive inhibition, in which the value of Vmax remains constant and the Km value increases.

  • Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half maximum.
  • Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction.
Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

 

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

The graph shows the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive inhibition.

Other options:

Option B: Non-competitive inhibition is by binding inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

The graph shows the changes in Vmax and Km in non-competitive inhibition.

Option C: In uncompetitive inhibition, inhibitors bind with the enzyme-substrate intermediate complex, and inhibit it. This leads to decrease in both Vmax and Km. An example is the inhibition of placental alkaline phosphate (ALP) by phenylalanine. 

Option D: Suicidal inhibition is a special type of irreversible inhibition. The inhibitor here makes use of the enzyme's own reaction mechanism to inactivate it and is hence known as mechanism-based inactivation. An example is allopurinol, which is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine. Alloxanthine in turn is a more potent inhibitor of xanthine oxidase. 

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

Related Pearl: Some Examples of Suicidal Inhibitors

questions.text:
In a patient with HIV, the incorrect statement regarding prophylaxis for various organisms is ____.

PCP- Pneumocystis pneumonia 

MAC- Mycobacterium avium complex

choices.text: Prophylaxis for PCP is indicated when CD count is <200 cells/µL
Stop prophylaxis for Coccidioides if CD count is >250 cells/µL for 6 months
Prophylaxis for MAC is indicated when CD count is <50 cells/µL
Prophylaxis for Cryptococcus is indicated when CD count is >150 cells/µL

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding prophylaxis in a patient with HIV is that prophylaxis for Cryptococcus is indicated when the CD count is >150 cells/µL.  

In cryptococcal infection, the indication for prophylaxis is a prior documented disease. The drugs used in prophylaxis can be oral fluconazole 200 mg/day or itraconazole 200 mg/day.

Prophylaxis can be stopped when CD4+ T-cell count is >100/μL and when there is no evidence of infection.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix
